para.paratext: Experts may come from any area of expertise. For example, a blacksmith was qualified as an expert witness to state his opinion regarding whether a steel hammer had been properly tempered and was suitable for use as a tool.[1]

Expert testimony based upon inadequate knowledge does not have to be excluded as the jury can determine the weight to give the opinion. In Southern Ry. Co. v. Montgomery,[2] the court held that an insufficiency of facts supporting an expert opinion goes to the weight and not the admissibility of the opinion. The Southern court cited Woods v. Andersen,[3] which stated the Georgia rule that juries are not required to accept expert opinion testimony. Southern upheld the admission of an expert's opinion which assumed a personal injury plaintiff would continue to be unemployed, even though this assumption was somewhat speculative. Moreover, the admissibility of expert testimony rendered against the DOT by an expert that was not an engineer was upheld because the underlying cause of action was not a professional negligence action, and therefore the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 24-7-702(c) did not apply.[4]

The court in Georgia Building Services, Inc. v. Perry[5] upheld testimony from an economist which could not be categorized as “sheer speculation.” Expert testimony based on sheer speculation is not admissible.

In Banker's Health and Life Ins. Co. v. Fryhofer,[6] the Georgia Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's decision to admit opinion evidence from an expert who testified for a lawyer who was suing for damages resulting from losing a client. The witness testified what would have happened if the lawyer had continued representing the client, including assuming that a jury would have returned a favorable verdict in a certain amount. The court stated, “speculation and conjecture by an expert is still speculation and conjecture, and will not support a verdict.”

In Fowler v. Campbell,[7] the trial court excluded speculative expert opinion testimony that the plaintiff in a slip-and-fall case had fallen due to the uneven nature of stairs that the plaintiff was climbing because there was no allegation that the plaintiff had fallen due to uneven stairs.

In Abney v. State,[8] the court excluded the expert testimony of a psychologist, who opined that defendant's test results and self-report were not suggestive of any sexual deviance towards minors, even though the testimony would have supported defendant's claim that he did not intend to have obscene internet contact with a minor, holding that said evidence went to the credibility and capability of the defendant committing the acts, and that such matters were within the ken of the jury and did not necessitate expert testimony. However, the Georgia Supreme Court has permitted evidence regarding the nature of injuries sustained as being likely intentional and not accidental, ruling that the testimony did not comment on the mental state of the defendant, but rather reflected on the nature of the injuries.[9]

An expert witness cannot base his opinion on the opinion of another witness, but may use facts introduced by other witnesses.[10] For example in a murder case, Gossett v. State,[11] a witness testified that he had found arsenic in the stomach of the deceased. Since this was a fact, it could be used in framing a hypothetical question for a second expert witness.

If an expert personally observes data collected by another, then his opinion is not objectionable merely because it is based, in part, on the other's findings. An expert must formulate his own opinion.[12]

Even when an expert's testimony is based on hearsay, the expert's lack of personal knowledge does not mandate the exclusion of the opinion but presents a jury question as to the weight, which should be accorded the opinion.[13] Moreover, testimony of an expert relying upon data that is of a type reasonably relied upon by experts in a particular field, such as a bonding evaluation by a psychologist in a termination case, is admissible.[14]
Southern R. Co. v. Cowan, 52 Ga. App. 360, 183 S.E. 331 (1936).
Southern Ry. Co. v. Montgomery, 192 Ga. App. 308, 384 S.E.2d 907 (1989).
Woods v. Andersen, 145 Ga. App. 492, 494, 243 S.E.2d 748 (1978).
Georgia Department of Transportation v. Delor, 2019 WL 2635639 (Ga. Ct. App. 2019).
Georgia Bldg. Services, Inc. v. Perry, 193 Ga. App. 288, 387 S.E.2d 898 (1989).
Bankers Health & Life Ins. Co. v. Fryhofer, 114 Ga. App. 107, 150 S.E.2d 365 (1966).
Fowler v. Campbell, 191 Ga. App. 872, 383 S.E.2d 163 (1989).
Abney v. State, 327 Ga. App. 551, 759 S.E.2d 618 (2014).
Walker v. Fields, 28 Ga. 237, 1859 WL 2541 (1859). See also O.C.G.A. § 24-7-703. Walker v. Fields was followed in Mallard v. Colonial Life & Acc. Ins. Co., 173 Ga. App. 276, 326 S.E.2d 6 (1985).

However, in Life Ins. Co. of Georgia v. Dodgen, 148 Ga. App. 725, 252 S.E.2d 629 (1979), the court stated: “The fact that other expert opinions were considered by the physician in reaching his ultimate conclusion does not render the evidence inadmissible.” Although this result might be desirable, it would be a change in the present rule. The Dodgen case was distinguished in Hyles v. Cockrill, 169 Ga. App. 132, 312 S.E.2d 124 (1983) (overruled by, Ketchup v. Howard, 247 Ga. App. 54, 543 S.E.2d 371 (2000)).
Gossett v. State, 203 Ga. 692, 48 S.E.2d 71 (1948). This case was considered in Vaughn v. State, 249 Ga. 803, 294 S.E.2d 504 (1982).
See Naji v. State, 300 Ga. 659, 797 S.E.2d 916 (2017), where the testimony of a medical examiner which was solely based on a colleague's work was admissible where the reports came in as work product.

But see Horton v. Hendrix, 291 Ga. App. 416, 662 S.E.2d 227 (2008) (not even an expert can give an opinion based entirely upon reports which have been prepared by others and which are not in evidence; a testifying expert is not to serve as a conduit for the opinions of others).
In Interest of R. S. T., 345 Ga. App. 300, 812 S.E.2d 614 (2018).
